generated_encounter_updates.reason_display_text: Patient Maria Gomez reports facial pain, pressure, and nasal congestion for 4 days.
generated_encounter_updates.transcript:
Clinician: Hello Maria, what brings you in today?
Maria: Hi Doctor. I've been having this awful pressure in my face, especially around my sinuses, for the past four days. And my nose is so stuffy.
Clinician: Any fever or colored nasal discharge?
Maria: No fever, but the discharge is a bit yellowish-green this morning.
Clinician: Okay, any headache or toothache?
Maria: Yes, a dull headache and some tenderness in my upper teeth.
Clinician: Let's take a look. (Performs exam) Your nasal passages are quite congested, and there's some tenderness over your maxillary sinuses. It looks like acute sinusitis.
Maria: Oh, I was worried it might be something like that.
Clinician: It's quite common. I'll prescribe a nasal corticosteroid spray to help with the inflammation and a decongestant. If you're not feeling better in a few days or if you develop a high fever, please come back.
Maria: Thank you, Doctor.
generated_encounter_updates.soap_note:
S: Maria Gomez, a 37-year-old female (DOB 1988-04-17), presents with a 4-day history of facial pain/pressure, nasal congestion, and yellowish-green nasal discharge noted today. Reports associated dull headache and upper tooth tenderness. Denies fever.
O: Afebrile. Maxillary sinus tenderness on TTP. Nasal mucosa erythematous and swollen with some purulent discharge noted. Pharynx WNL. Lungs CTA.
A: Acute sinusitis, likely bacterial given purulent discharge and duration.
Differential diagnoses: Viral URI with prolonged symptoms, Allergic rhinitis.
P: 1. Prescribe Amoxicillin-clavulanate 875/125 mg PO BID for 7 days. 2. Recommend Fluticasone nasal spray, 2 sprays each nostril daily. 3. Recommend Pseudoephedrine 60mg PO Q6H PRN for congestion. 4. Advise steam inhalation, saline nasal rinses. 5. Patient to follow up if symptoms worsen or do not improve in 3-5 days, or if fever develops.
generated_encounter_updates.observations: Patient appears uncomfortable but in no acute distress. Mild post-nasal drip observed. Good air entry bilaterally.

treatments.instructions: Take with food. Complete full course.
Shake well before use.
For nasal congestion. Do not exceed 4 doses in 24 hours.

generated_conditions.note: Symptoms include facial pain, congestion, and purulent nasal discharge.
Considered, but sinusitis more likely given facial pressure and purulent discharge.

generated_encounter_updates.reason_display_text: Patient James Lee reports persistent low back pain for 2 weeks, worse with activity.
generated_encounter_updates.transcript:
Clinician: Good morning James, what seems to be the problem today?
James: Hi Doctor. I've been having this really bothersome low back pain for about two weeks now.
Clinician: Can you describe the pain? Is it sharp, dull, aching? Does it radiate anywhere?
James: It's mostly a dull ache, but sometimes it gets sharp if I move the wrong way. It doesn't really go down my legs, just stays in my lower back.
Clinician: Any numbness, tingling, or weakness in your legs? Any issues with bowel or bladder control?
James: No, none of that, thankfully.
Clinician: What makes it worse or better?
James: It's definitely worse when I'm active, like lifting things or even just standing for too long. Resting helps a bit, and ibuprofen takes the edge off.
Clinician: Any recent injury or specific event that triggered it?
James: Not really an injury, but I did help a friend move some heavy furniture about two weeks ago. It started a day or so after that.
Clinician: Alright, let's get you on the exam table and take a look. (Performs physical exam). There's some tenderness in your lumbar paraspinal muscles and some limited range of motion on flexion. Straight leg raise is negative. Based on your history and exam, it sounds like acute lumbar strain.
James: Is that serious?
Clinician: Usually not. It's a common muscle strain. I'll recommend some gentle stretching exercises, continued use of ibuprofen or naproxen as needed, and applying heat or ice. Try to avoid heavy lifting for a bit. If it's not improving in a week or two, or if you develop any new symptoms like leg weakness or numbness, we'll need to re-evaluate.
James: Okay, that sounds manageable. Thanks, Doctor.
generated_encounter_updates.soap_note:
S: James Lee, a 52-year-old male (DOB 1972-11-05), presents with a 2-week history of low back pain. Describes pain as dull ache, occasionally sharp with movement, localized to the lumbosacral region. No radiation, numbness, or weakness in lower extremities. Denies bowel/bladder incontinence. Pain exacerbated by activity and lifting, relieved by rest and NSAIDs. Onset occurred after helping move heavy furniture.
O: VS: WNL. Lumbar spine exam: Tenderness to palpation over L4-L5 paraspinal muscles bilaterally. ROM: Lumbar flexion limited to 60 degrees due to pain, extension and lateral bending WNL. Straight leg raise negative bilaterally. Neurological exam: Motor strength 5/5 in lower extremities, sensation intact to light touch, DTRs 2+ and symmetric.
A: Acute Lumbar Strain (M54.50).
Differential diagnoses: Herniated lumbar disc (less likely without radiculopathy), Spondylolisthesis.
P: 1. Conservative management: Continue NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen 400-600mg Q6-8H PRN). 2. Apply heat/ice to affected area. 3. Gentle stretching exercises for low back; provide handout. 4. Activity modification: Avoid heavy lifting and strenuous activities. 5. Patient education on proper body mechanics. 6. Follow up in 2 weeks if not improved, or sooner if symptoms worsen or new neurological deficits develop.
generated_encounter_updates.observations: Patient moves cautiously. No gross deformities noted on inspection of the back. Gait is normal.

treatments.instructions: Take with food to minimize GI upset.
Apply heat or ice to the lower back for 15-20 minutes, several times a day.
Perform gentle stretches as per handout, 1-2 times daily.
Avoid heavy lifting and strenuous activities until pain subsides. Gradually return to normal activities.

generated_conditions.note: Attributed to lumbar strain after heavy lifting.

generated_conditions.description: Other specified intervertebral disc displacement, lumbar region
generated_conditions.note: Considered, but less likely given absence of radicular symptoms.

generated_encounter_updates.reason_display_text: Follow-up for Justin Rodriguez, right knee pain, previously diagnosed as rheumatoid arthritis.
generated_encounter_updates.transcript:
Clinician: Hello Justin, good to see you again. How has your right knee been feeling since our last visit?
Justin: Hi Dr. Smith. It's been up and down. Some days it's not too bad, just a bit stiff in the morning. Other days, especially if I've been on my feet a lot, it really aches and swells up a bit.
Clinician: Are you still taking the methotrexate and folic acid as prescribed?
Justin: Yes, consistently. And the naproxen when the pain gets worse.
Clinician: Any new joint involvement or other symptoms like fatigue or fever?
Justin: My hands have been a little stiff too, especially in the mornings, but not as bad as the knee. I do feel more tired than usual lately.
Clinician: Okay. Let's examine your knee. (Performs exam) There's some mild effusion in the right knee and tenderness along the medial joint line. Range of motion is slightly reduced compared to the left. Any side effects from the methotrexate?
Justin: Just some occasional mild nausea, but it's manageable.
Clinician: We did some blood tests last week. Your ESR and CRP are still a bit elevated, though slightly better than before. The rheumatoid factor remains positive. It seems your RA is still moderately active. I think we should continue with the current dose of methotrexate for now, but let's discuss adding a short course of low-dose oral corticosteroids to help manage this flare-up in your knee and the increasing fatigue.
Justin: Steroids? Are there many side effects?
Clinician: We'll use a low dose for a short period, which minimizes risks. It can be very effective in quickly reducing inflammation and pain. We'll monitor you closely. I also want to refer you to a physiotherapist to work on range of motion and strengthening exercises for your knee.
Justin: Okay, Doctor. I'm willing to try if it helps.
generated_encounter_updates.soap_note:
S: Justin Rodriguez, a 103-year-old male (DOB 1921-08-22), presents for follow-up of Rheumatoid Arthritis, primarily affecting the right knee. Reports variable knee pain and stiffness, worse with activity. Morning stiffness in hands noted. Increased fatigue recently. Adherent to methotrexate 15mg weekly, folic acid, and PRN naproxen. Occasional mild nausea with methotrexate.
O: VS: WNL. Right Knee: Mild effusion, tenderness on medial joint line. ROM: Flexion to 110 degrees (Left 130), extension to 0 degrees. Mild crepitus. Hands: No active synovitis, mild MCP stiffness. Recent Labs (from 2025-05-22): ESR 35 mm/hr (elevated), CRP 12 mg/L (elevated), RF positive.
A: Rheumatoid Arthritis, moderately active. Flare affecting right knee. Increased fatigue possibly related to RA activity or methotrexate.
P: 1. Continue Methotrexate 15mg weekly and Folic Acid 1mg daily. 2. Start Prednisone 5mg PO daily for 2 weeks, then taper by 1mg every 3 days if symptoms improve. 3. Continue Naproxen 500mg PO BID PRN for pain. 4. Refer to Physiotherapy for right knee and general RA management. 5. Repeat inflammatory markers (ESR, CRP) in 4 weeks. 6. Follow up in 4 weeks to assess response to steroid and physiotherapy, and to monitor for methotrexate side effects.
generated_encounter_updates.observations: Patient appears fatigued but in good spirits. Right knee shows mild swelling. Mild tenderness over MCP joints of both hands on palpation.

treatments.instructions: Take as prescribed. Monitor for side effects.
Take with methotrexate to reduce side effects.
Start 5mg daily for 2 weeks, then reduce dose by 1mg every 3 days as tolerated. To manage acute flare.
Take with food.
For right knee range of motion, strengthening, and general RA management strategies.

generated_conditions.description: Rheumatoid arthritis with rheumatoid factor of right knee without organ or systems involvement
generated_conditions.note: Long-standing RA, currently experiencing a flare.

generated_conditions.description: Rheumatoid arthritis without rheumatoid factor of right knee
generated_conditions.note: Acute flare of known RA in the right knee. Based on current symptoms.
Considered, but inflammatory markers and history point more to RA flare.

generated_encounter_updates.reason_display_text: Patient Bob Jones for chronic fatigue and joint pain, follow-up after positive RA serology.
generated_encounter_updates.transcript:
Clinician: Hi Bob, come in. We're here to discuss the fatigue and joint pain you've been experiencing, and we have the results of your blood tests.
Bob: Thanks, Doctor. Yes, it's been ongoing for a few months now, and it's really starting to affect my daily life. I'm just tired all the time, and my joints, especially my hands and knees, are stiff and achy, worse in the mornings.
Clinician: I see. And the blood tests confirm our suspicion. Your inflammatory markers, the ESR and CRP, are elevated. Also, the rheumatoid factor and anti-CCP antibodies came back positive.
Bob: What does that mean?
Clinician: These results, along with your symptoms of morning stiffness in multiple joints and persistent fatigue, confirm a diagnosis of Rheumatoid Arthritis. This is an autoimmune condition where your body's immune system mistakenly attacks your joints.
Bob: Rheumatoid Arthritis... I've heard of it. Is it serious?
Clinician: It's a chronic condition, Bob, but with appropriate management, we can control the symptoms and prevent joint damage. The goal is to reduce inflammation and pain, and maintain your joint function. We usually start with medications called DMARDs, Disease-Modifying Anti-Rheumatic Drugs. Methotrexate is often the first choice. We'll also discuss lifestyle adjustments and I'll refer you to a rheumatologist for specialized care.
Bob: Okay. Methotrexate... are there side effects?
Clinician: Like all medications, it can have side effects, which we'll discuss in detail. We monitor you closely with regular blood tests. We'll also prescribe folic acid to help reduce some potential side effects. For now, I'll also prescribe some stronger anti-inflammatory medication to help with the immediate pain and stiffness.
Bob: Alright, Doctor. Let's do what we need to do.
generated_encounter_updates.soap_note:
S: Bob Jones, a 74-year-old male (DOB 1950-07-07), presents for follow-up of chronic fatigue and widespread joint pain for several months. Reports significant morning stiffness in hands and knees lasting over an hour. Pain rated 6/10, aching in nature. Input reason was 'Fatigue and joint pain'.
O: VS: WNL. Musculoskeletal: Swelling and tenderness noted in MCP and PIP joints of both hands. Mild effusion and tenderness in both knees. Limited ROM in affected joints due to pain and stiffness. Recent Labs: ESR 45mm/hr (H), CRP 25mg/L (H), RF Positive (1:80), Anti-CCP Positive (>250 U/mL).
A: Rheumatoid Arthritis, seropositive, active (M05.79 - RA with RF of multiple sites).
Differential diagnoses: Osteoarthritis (less likely given inflammatory markers and symmetry), Polymyalgia Rheumatica (less likely given joint distribution and RF/CCP status), Viral arthropathy (less likely given chronicity).
P: 1. Start Methotrexate 10mg PO once weekly. 2. Prescribe Folic Acid 1mg PO daily (except on methotrexate day). 3. Prescribe Naproxen 500mg PO BID for symptomatic relief. 4. Patient education on RA, methotrexate, and importance of regular monitoring (CBC, LFTs, renal function q4-8 weeks). 5. Referral to Rheumatology for co-management. 6. Schedule follow-up in 4 weeks to assess response and monitor labs.
generated_encounter_updates.observations: Patient appears fatigued. Bilateral symmetrical joint involvement observed in hands and knees. No skin rashes or other systemic signs noted today.

treatments.instructions: Take on the same day each week. Avoid alcohol. Report any signs of infection or shortness of breath.
Take daily, but skip on the day of methotrexate dose.
Take with food. Monitor for GI side effects.
For specialist co-management of Rheumatoid Arthritis.

generated_conditions.description: Rheumatoid arthritis with rheumatoid factor of multiple sites
generated_conditions.note: Diagnosed based on symptoms (fatigue, joint pain, morning stiffness) and positive serology (RF, Anti-CCP).
Considered due to age and joint pain, but inflammatory markers and symmetrical small joint involvement more consistent with RA.
Significant component of presenting symptoms, likely related to RA activity.

generated_lab_results.name: Rheumatoid Factor (RF)
generated_lab_results.interpretation: Positive, supports diagnosis of Rheumatoid Arthritis.

generated_lab_results.name: Anti-Cyclic Citrullinated Peptide (Anti-CCP) Antibodies
generated_lab_results.interpretation: Highly positive, strongly supports diagnosis of Rheumatoid Arthritis.

generated_encounter_updates.reason_display_text: Patient Eleanor Thompson reports recurrent episodes of dizziness, difficulty walking, and nausea for the past month.
generated_encounter_updates.transcript:
Clinician: Good morning, Eleanor. Please tell me what's been troubling you.
Eleanor: Hello Doctor. For the past month, I've been having these spells of dizziness. It feels like the room is spinning, and I have trouble keeping my balance, especially when I try to walk. Sometimes I feel quite nauseous too.
Clinician: I see. How long do these episodes last?
Eleanor: They can last anywhere from 20 minutes to a few hours. It's quite debilitating when it happens.
Clinician: Any hearing loss or ringing in your ears associated with these episodes?
Eleanor: Yes, during the bad spells, I notice my hearing in my left ear seems muffled, and there's a sort of low roaring sound.
Clinician: Have you had any falls because of the dizziness?
Eleanor: I've stumbled a few times, but thankfully no serious falls yet. I'm very careful now.
Clinician: We'll need to do a thorough neurological and ear examination. Based on your symptoms – the vertigo, hearing changes, and tinnitus – one possibility is Meniere's disease. The initial intake note was for 'Difficulty walking and dizziness'. We'll also consider other causes of vertigo. I'll order an audiogram to check your hearing formally.
Eleanor: Meniere's disease? What does that involve?
Clinician: It's a disorder of the inner ear. For now, I can prescribe some medication to help with the dizziness and nausea during acute episodes. We'll also discuss some lifestyle changes that might help, like a low-salt diet.
Eleanor: Okay, Doctor. I hope we can find something that helps.
generated_encounter_updates.soap_note:
S: Eleanor Thompson, an 84-year-old female (DOB 1940-12-25), presents with a one-month history of recurrent episodes of vertigo (room spinning), gait instability, and nausea. Episodes last 20 minutes to several hours. Reports associated left-sided hearing loss (muffled) and low-pitched tinnitus ('roaring') during episodes. Denies syncope but has stumbled. No recent head trauma.
O: VS: WNL. Neuro: Cranial nerves II-XII intact. Cerebellar exam: Mild difficulty with tandem gait, Romberg negative with eyes open, sways with eyes closed. Otoscopy: TMs clear bilaterally. Weber test lateralizes to right. Rinne: AC > BC bilaterally.
A: Recurrent Vertigo with associated auditory symptoms. Suspect Meniere's Disease, left ear (H81.02).
Differential diagnoses: Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV), Vestibular Neuronitis, Labyrinthitis, Acoustic Neuroma (less likely given fluctuant hearing loss).
P: 1. Prescribe Meclizine 25mg PO TID PRN for vertigo. 2. Prescribe Ondansetron 4mg ODT Q8H PRN for nausea. 3. Refer for Audiogram and Vestibular Function Tests (VNG). 4. Counsel on low-sodium diet (<2g/day). 5. Advise fall precautions. 6. Follow up in 2 weeks to review test results and assess symptomatic response.
generated_encounter_updates.observations: Patient appears anxious about her symptoms. Uses a cane for ambulation today. Mild nystagmus observed during Hallpike maneuver, but not characteristic of BPPV.

treatments.instructions: May cause drowsiness. Avoid driving if affected.
Allow to dissolve on tongue.
Advised to limit dietary sodium intake to less than 2 grams per day.
To formally assess hearing and vestibular function.

generated_conditions.note: Classic triad of vertigo, tinnitus, and fluctuating hearing loss.
Considered due to vertigo, but associated auditory symptoms make Meniere's more likely.

generated_conditions.description: Difficulty in walking, not elsewhere classified
generated_conditions.note: Secondary to vertigo episodes.
Primary presenting symptom, described as vertigo.

generated_lab_results.name: TSH (Thyroid Stimulating Hormone)
generated_lab_results.interpretation: Within normal limits, rules out hypothyroidism as a cause of fatigue/dizziness.

generated_encounter_updates.reason_display_text: Patient Alice Smith reports cough, runny nose, and mild sore throat for 2 days. Denies fever.
generated_encounter_updates.transcript:
Clinician: Hello Alice, what brings you in today?
Alice: Hi Doctor. I've had this annoying cough and a runny nose for a couple of days. A bit of a scratchy throat too.
Clinician: Any fever, body aches, or difficulty breathing?
Alice: No fever, thankfully. Just feeling a bit tired from the cough.
Clinician: Let me take a look. (Performs brief exam) Your throat is slightly red, and your lungs sound clear. It looks like a common viral upper respiratory infection.
Alice: Oh, okay. So, nothing too serious?
Clinician: Not at this stage. I recommend getting plenty of rest, staying hydrated, and you can use some over-the-counter lozenges for your throat. If your symptoms worsen or you develop a fever, please come back.
Alice: Sounds good. Thank you, Doctor.
generated_encounter_updates.soap_note:
S: Alice Smith, a 35-year-old female (DOB 1990-01-01), reports a 2-day history of cough (non-productive), rhinorrhea (clear), and mild pharyngitis ('scratchy throat'). Denies fever, chills, dyspnea, or myalgia. States she feels 'a bit tired'. No significant PMH.
O: Temp 37.0C (oral), HR 78 bpm, RR 16/min, BP 120/75 mmHg, SpO2 99% RA. General: Alert, no acute distress. HEENT: Pharynx mildly erythematous, no exudate. Nasal mucosa mildly congested, clear discharge. TMs clear. Neck: Supple, no lymphadenopathy. Lungs: CTA bilaterally, no wheezes or rales.
A: Acute Viral Upper Respiratory Infection (URI) (J06.9).
Differential diagnoses: Allergic rhinitis (J30.9), COVID-19 (U07.1) (pending test if indicated by local guidelines/symptoms worsen).
P: 1. Symptomatic relief: Recommend rest, increased fluid intake (water, tea). 2. OTC throat lozenges for pharyngitis. 3. Saline nasal spray for congestion. 4. Advise patient to monitor for worsening symptoms (fever >38.5C, shortness of breath, productive cough with colored sputum) and to return or seek further medical advice if these develop. 5. No antibiotics indicated as likely viral etiology. 6. Hand hygiene and cough etiquette reinforced.
generated_encounter_updates.observations: Patient is alert and oriented, in no acute distress. Mild nasal congestion observed. Pharynx shows mild erythema without exudates.

treatments.instructions: Advised patient to get adequate rest and increase fluid intake (water, tea, broth).
Use as needed for nasal congestion relief.
Use as needed for sore throat relief.

generated_conditions.note: Symptoms consistent with common cold: cough, rhinorrhea, mild pharyngitis. No fever.
Considered due to nasal symptoms, but lack of itching and acute onset makes URI more likely.

generated_lab_results.name: Rapid Influenza Diagnostic Test (RIDT)
generated_lab_results.interpretation: Influenza A and B not detected.

generated_encounter_updates.reason_display_text: Patient Charlie Brown presents with recurrent headaches, described as throbbing, unilateral, with associated photophobia and nausea for 6 months.
generated_encounter_updates.transcript:
Clinician: Hi Charlie, thanks for coming in. You mentioned on the phone you've been having some headaches?
Charlie: Yes, Doctor. They've been happening for about six months now, maybe a couple of times a month. It's a throbbing pain, usually on one side of my head, often behind my eye.
Clinician: I see. When these headaches occur, do you notice any other symptoms? Like sensitivity to light or sound, or any nausea?
Charlie: Definitely sensitive to light. I just want to be in a dark room. And sometimes I feel nauseous, though I haven't actually vomited.
Clinician: Any visual disturbances before or during the headache, like flashing lights or blind spots?
Charlie: No, nothing like that.
Clinician: What do you typically do when you get one? Does anything make it better or worse?
Charlie: I usually take some ibuprofen and try to lie down in a quiet, dark room. That helps a bit. Stress seems to make them more frequent.
Clinician: Alright. We'll do a neurological exam which seems normal today. Based on your description – the unilateral, throbbing nature, photophobia, and nausea – this sounds very much like migraine without aura. We can discuss some treatment options, both for acute attacks and potentially for prevention if they are frequent enough to impact your quality of life.
Charlie: Migraine? I thought those were more severe. These are bad, but I can usually function, albeit miserably.
Clinician: Migraines vary greatly in severity. What you're describing fits the criteria. Let's talk about some specific migraine medications you can try at the onset of a headache, and we can also look at lifestyle factors and triggers.
Charlie: Okay, I'm open to suggestions.
generated_encounter_updates.soap_note:
S: Charlie Brown, a 40-year-old male (DOB 1985-05-15), reports a 6-month history of episodic headaches occurring 2-3 times per month. Describes headaches as unilateral (often right-sided, retro-orbital), throbbing, lasting 4-24 hours. Associated symptoms include photophobia and nausea. Denies aura, visual disturbances, or neurological deficits. Pain severity 6-8/10. Relieved partially by OTC ibuprofen and rest in a dark room. Identifies stress as a possible trigger. No red flag symptoms.
O: VS: WNL. Neuro exam: CN II-XII intact, motor strength 5/5 throughout, sensation intact, reflexes 2+ symmetric, cerebellar function normal. No papilledema on fundoscopy (deferred to ophthalmology if chronic/worsening).
A: Migraine without aura (G43.009).
Differential diagnoses: Tension-type headache (less likely given unilateral throbbing and associated symptoms), Cluster headache (less likely given duration and lack of autonomic symptoms).
P: 1. Prescribe Sumatriptan 50mg PO, take 1 tablet at onset of migraine, may repeat x1 after 2 hours if no relief (max 100mg/24h). 2. Advise keeping a headache diary to identify triggers. 3. Discuss lifestyle modifications: regular sleep, stress management, hydration. 4. Counsel on avoiding overuse of acute medications. 5. Follow up in 4-6 weeks to assess efficacy and frequency. Consider prophylactic medication if headaches are frequent or debilitating despite acute treatment.
generated_encounter_updates.observations: Patient is articulate and provides a clear history. Appears generally well today. No focal neurological deficits on examination. Original input `transcript` field for this record was `This is a test`, this has been replaced with a relevant clinical transcript.

treatments.frequency: At onset of migraine, may repeat x1 after 2 hours
treatments.instructions: Take at first sign of migraine. Max 100mg in 24 hours. Do not use more than 10 days per month.
Advised to keep a detailed diary of headache frequency, severity, duration, triggers, and response to medication.
Discussed basic stress reduction techniques and recommended exploring options like mindfulness or exercise.

generated_conditions.description: Migraine without aura, not intractable, without status migrainosus
generated_conditions.note: Recurrent unilateral throbbing headaches with photophobia and nausea.
Considered, but features like unilateral pain and photophobia are more suggestive of migraine.

generated_encounter_updates.reason_display_text: Diana Wilson, 10 y/o female, presents with right ear pain and fever for 24 hours.
generated_encounter_updates.transcript:
Clinician: Hello Diana, and hello Mom/Dad. What's going on with Diana today?
Parent: She's been complaining of pain in her right ear since yesterday, Doctor. And she had a fever last night around 101.5°F.
Clinician: Diana, can you point to where it hurts?
Diana: (Points to right ear) It really hurts in here.
Clinician: Any trouble hearing from that ear? Any discharge or fluid coming out?
Diana: It feels a bit blocked. No yucky stuff coming out though.
Parent: She's also been a bit fussier than usual and didn't eat much dinner last night.
Clinician: Any recent cold or runny nose, Diana?
Diana: I had a little cold last week.
Clinician: Okay, let me take a look in your ears and throat. (Performs otoscopy and pharyngeal exam) Well, Diana, your right eardrum is red and bulging, and it doesn't move well when I puff some air. Your left ear looks fine, and your throat is clear. This looks like an acute middle ear infection, or what we call acute otitis media, in your right ear.
Parent: Oh dear. Does she need antibiotics?
Clinician: Given her age, the fever, and the appearance of the eardrum, antibiotics are recommended. Amoxicillin is usually the first choice if there are no allergies. We'll also give some advice on pain and fever management.
Diana: Will it make my ear stop hurting?
Clinician: Yes, the medicine will help fight the infection, and we'll talk about some pain medicine to make you feel more comfortable quickly.
Parent: Okay, thank you, Doctor.
generated_encounter_updates.soap_note:
S: Diana Wilson, a 10-year-old female (DOB 2015-03-20), presents with parent reporting a 24-hour history of right ear pain and subjective fever (Tmax 101.5°F at home). Associated fussiness and decreased appetite. Reports recent URI symptoms last week. Complains of right ear feeling 'blocked'. Denies ear discharge.
O: VS: Temp 38.2°C (tympanic), HR 90 bpm, RR 20/min. General: Appears uncomfortable, tearful at times. HEENT: Right TM erythematous, bulging, with loss of landmarks and impaired mobility on pneumatic otoscopy. Left TM WNL. Pharynx clear. Nasal mucosa mildly congested. Neck: Supple, no significant lymphadenopathy.
A: Acute Otitis Media (AOM), right ear (H66.001).
P: 1. Prescribe Amoxicillin 90 mg/kg/day divided BID (e.g., if 30kg, 1350mg BID, usually as suspension) for 7 days. 2. Recommend Acetaminophen or Ibuprofen PRN for pain and fever, dosed appropriately for weight. 3. Advise parent on signs of worsening infection (persistent high fever, increased pain, mastoid tenderness, lethargy) and to seek re-evaluation if symptoms do not improve in 48-72 hours or worsen. 4. Follow-up if symptoms persist after completion of antibiotics or if recurrent infections.
generated_encounter_updates.observations: Child is cooperative but clearly in discomfort. Right ear exam findings are classic for AOM. No signs of mastoiditis or other complications.

treatments.instructions: Complete full course of antibiotics. Shake well before use. May take with food.

treatments.frequency: PRN Q4-6H for acetaminophen, Q6-8H for ibuprofen
treatments.instructions: For symptomatic relief of pain and fever. Do not exceed recommended daily dosage.

generated_conditions.description: Acute suppurative otitis media without spontaneous rupture of eardrum, right ear
generated_conditions.note: Right TM red, bulging, with impaired mobility. Associated fever and ear pain.

generated_conditions.description: Other acute nonsuppurative otitis media, right ear
generated_conditions.note: Considered, but suppurative features (bulging, erythema) are more prominent.

generated_encounter_updates.reason_display_text: Patient Sandra Mitchell presents with abdominal pain and diarrhea for the past week.
generated_encounter_updates.transcript:
Clinician: Good morning, Sandra. Tell me what's been going on.
Sandra: Hi Doctor. For the past week, I've been having this cramping pain in my abdomen, mostly on the lower right side. And I've had diarrhea pretty frequently, maybe 5-6 times a day.
Clinician: Any blood in the stool? Fever? Weight loss?
Sandra: I think I saw a little bit of blood once or twice, mixed in. No fever that I've noticed. I do feel like I've lost a few pounds, but I haven't been eating much because of the pain.
Clinician: Any other symptoms? Joint pain, skin rashes, eye problems?
Sandra: Not really, just feeling very tired.
Clinician: Okay. Let's do an examination. (Performs abdominal exam). There's some tenderness in your right lower quadrant. We'll need to run some tests to figure out what's causing this. This could be an inflammatory bowel condition like Crohn's disease, or perhaps an infection. We'll start with some blood tests to check for inflammation and anemia, and a stool sample to look for infection and inflammation markers.
Sandra: Crohn's disease? That sounds serious.
Clinician: It's a chronic inflammatory condition, but it's manageable. The tests will help us clarify. Depending on those results, we might need to do a colonoscopy to get a better look at your intestines. For now, let's try to manage your symptoms. I can prescribe something to help with the diarrhea and pain.
Sandra: Okay, Doctor. What kind of tests are these?
generated_encounter_updates.soap_note:
S: Sandra Mitchell, a 54-year-old female (DOB 1970-07-25), presents with a one-week history of cramping abdominal pain, primarily in the RLQ, and non-bloody diarrhea (5-6 episodes/day). Reports some fatigue and possible unintentional weight loss (few pounds). Notes seeing a small amount of blood in stool on one occasion. Denies fever, significant joint pain or skin rashes.
O: VS: WNL. Abdomen: Soft, moderate tenderness to palpation in RLQ, no rebound or guarding. Bowel sounds active. No organomegaly.
A: Suspected Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD), likely Crohn's disease given RLQ pain and possible weight loss.
Differential diagnoses: Infectious colitis also in differential.
P: 1. Blood tests: CBC, CMP, ESR, CRP. 2. Stool studies: Culture & sensitivity, O&P, C. difficile toxin assay, fecal calprotectin. 3. Prescribe Loperamide 2mg PO after each loose stool (max 16mg/day) for symptomatic relief of diarrhea. 4. Prescribe Dicyclomine 10mg PO QID PRN for abdominal cramping. 5. Follow up in 3-5 days to review initial results and discuss further management, including potential colonoscopy. 6. Advise bland diet, maintain hydration.
generated_encounter_updates.observations: Patient appears tired but in no acute distress. Abdominal exam reveals tenderness in the right lower quadrant. No signs of peritonitis.

treatments.instructions: For symptomatic relief of diarrhea.
May cause drowsiness.

treatments.treatment_name: STAT Labs (CBC, CMP, ESR, CRP, Stool studies)
treatments.instructions: Collect samples today for inflammatory markers, infection, and fecal calprotectin.
Recommend bland diet, avoid high-fiber foods during acute symptoms. Maintain hydration.

generated_conditions.note: Presenting with RLQ abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss. Awaiting test results.
Considered due to acute onset of diarrhea. Stool studies pending.
Also considered in the differential for acute diarrhea and abdominal pain.

generated_lab_results.name: Fecal Calprotectin
generated_lab_results.interpretation: Significantly elevated, indicates intestinal inflammation. Consistent with IBD.

generated_lab_results.name: Hemoglobin
generated_lab_results.interpretation: Mild anemia, possibly due to chronic inflammation or malabsorption.

generated_lab_results.name: Albumin
generated_lab_results.interpretation: Low albumin, may indicate malnutrition or protein-losing enteropathy.
